explanations.a: Correct. NFA stands for Non-deterministic Finite Automaton, which allows multiple transitions from a state on the same input symbol.
explanations.b: Incorrect. NFA does not stand for New Finite Automaton.
explanations.c: Incorrect. NFA does not stand for Normal Finite Automaton.
explanations.d: Incorrect. NFA does not stand for Nested Finite Automaton.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key difference between NFA and DFA?

answers.a: DFA has more states than NFA
answers.b: NFA can have multiple transitions from one state on the same input

explanations.a: Incorrect. The number of states depends on the specific automaton, not the type.
explanations.b: Correct. NFAs can have multiple transitions from a single state on the same input symbol, while DFAs have exactly one transition.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Both NFAs and DFAs can use the same alphabet.
explanations.d: Incorrect. NFAs can and do have accepting states.

questions.question: What are epsilon (ε) transitions in an NFA?

answers.b: Transitions that don't consume any input symbol

explanations.a: Incorrect. Regular transitions consume input symbols, but epsilon transitions do not.
explanations.b: Correct. Epsilon transitions allow the automaton to move between states without consuming any input symbol.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Epsilon transitions can lead to any state, not just accepting states.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Epsilon transitions do not reject input; they are used for state transitions.

questions.question: What is the epsilon closure of a set of states?

answers.a: The set of states reachable using only input symbols
answers.b: The set of all accepting states
answers.c: The set of states reachable using only epsilon transitions
answers.d: The set of states that reject input

explanations.a: Incorrect. This describes states reachable by regular transitions, not epsilon closure.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Epsilon closure is not related to accepting states specifically.
explanations.c: Correct. The epsilon closure includes the original states plus all states reachable through epsilon transitions only.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Epsilon closure is not related to rejection of input.

questions.question: In the subset construction algorithm, each DFA state represents:

explanations.a: Incorrect. DFA states in subset construction represent multiple NFA states.
explanations.b: Correct. Each DFA state corresponds to a subset of NFA states that the NFA could be in simultaneously.
explanations.c: Incorrect. DFA states do not represent transitions.
explanations.d: Incorrect. DFA states do not represent input symbols.

questions.question: When is a DFA state considered accepting in the subset construction?

answers.a: When it contains only accepting NFA states
answers.b: When it contains at least one accepting NFA state
answers.c: When it is the start state
answers.d: When it has no outgoing transitions

explanations.a: Incorrect. A DFA state is accepting even if it contains non-accepting NFA states, as long as it contains at least one accepting NFA state.
explanations.b: Correct. A DFA state is accepting if it contains at least one accepting state from the original NFA.
explanations.c: Incorrect. The start state is not necessarily accepting unless it meets the condition in option b.
explanations.d: Incorrect. The presence of outgoing transitions does not determine if a state is accepting.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of the subset construction algorithm in the worst case?

explanations.a: Incorrect. The worst-case complexity is much higher than linear.
explanations.b: Incorrect. The worst-case complexity is exponential, not quadratic.
explanations.c: Correct. In the worst case, the subset construction can create up to 2^n DFA states for an NFA with n states.
explanations.d: Incorrect. The worst-case complexity is exponential, not O(n log n).

questions.question: Which statement about DFA minimization is correct?

answers.a: All DFAs can be minimized to have exactly one state
answers.b: DFA minimization always reduces the number of states
answers.c: The minimized DFA accepts a different language than the original
answers.d: DFA minimization removes equivalent states while preserving the accepted language

explanations.a: Incorrect. Not all DFAs can be minimized to one state; it depends on the language they accept.
explanations.b: Incorrect. If a DFA is already minimal, minimization won't reduce the number of states.
explanations.c: Incorrect. The minimized DFA must accept exactly the same language as the original DFA.
explanations.d: Correct. DFA minimization identifies and merges equivalent states while ensuring the same language is accepted.

questions.question: What is the relationship between the languages accepted by an NFA and its equivalent DFA?

answers.a: The DFA accepts a subset of the NFA's language
answers.b: The NFA accepts a subset of the DFA's language
answers.c: They accept exactly the same language

explanations.a: Incorrect. The DFA accepts exactly the same language as the NFA, not a subset.
explanations.b: Incorrect. The NFA accepts exactly the same language as the DFA, not a subset.
explanations.c: Correct. By definition, an NFA and its equivalent DFA constructed through subset construction accept exactly the same language.
explanations.d: Incorrect. An NFA and its equivalent DFA must accept the same language to be considered equivalent.
